Subject: - Standard Operating Procedure for Operationalisation of Radi logical

In exercise of powers conferred by Section SA of the Aircraft Act. 1934 (XXII
of 1934), read with rule 3 (b) of the Aireraft (Security) Rules, 2011, Director General, as
Bureau of Civil Aviation Security (DG, BCAS), for the purpose of the safety of
passengers, crew, ground personnel and the general public in all matters relating to
safeguarding against acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation and Radiological
threats in particular, delineates the Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for handling
of Radiological Detection Equipment to prevent emerging radiological threats ftom
entry/exit points at Indian airports. A copy of these Standard Operating Procedures for
RDE is enclosed herewith for strict compliance by all concerned.

2. All stakeholders working at the airports are responsible for adhering to the
guidelines and their implementation mentioned in the SOP. Radiological Detection
Equipment will he operationalized by Aviation Security Group (ASG) with immediate
effect and upkeep & maintenance will lie with the Airport Operators. Under no
circumstances the equipment will be kept idle by ASG/Airport Operators, as RDEs
have been installed as preventive measures ut Airports in accordance with instruction
issued by Cabinet Secretariat, Government of India.

3 ‘The mock exercise related to radiological emergencies shall be conducted at er
airports once in a year with participation of all responsible agencies (ASG, NDRF,
BARC, Local Police, etc.) as per coordinated schedules without spreading panic
among the passengers. The Mock exercise shall be conducted by ASG/Airport
operators under intimation/ in the presence of BCAS representative. Data pertaining to
Radiological Emergency Mock Exercise (REME) shall be kept in recard for Audit and

inspection purposes.

91 Do’s:- Radiological/Nuclear Disasters-

Any radiation incident resulting in or having a potential to result in exposures and or
contamination of the workers public or environment in excess of the respective permissible
limit can lead to a nuclear/radiological emergency.

Incase of thefi/loss of radioactive source from the institution/premises/during transportation,
it would normally be noticed first by the field person responsible for handling the same. The
head of the concerned organization would be next person to get this information from his
own field person. He in turn, would bring the incident to the notice of the local police station
as well as to the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) who is the regulator (as ,~
Radiation Protection Rule 2004 under the Atomic Energy Act) for transportation, storages
and use of radiation source in the public domain. This will be the trigger mechanism for
initiating any mitigation processes by the states agencies.

Further in case of Joss/theft of radioactive sources, the recommended response plan for
recovery/retrieval and disposal of the radiological source would be as follow:

1) ABRB will inform the Crisis Management Group (CMG), DAE through DAE
Emergency Control Room (DAE-ECR), Contact Details of 24 x 7 operational DAB-
Emergency Control Rooms are- main DAE-ECR{022-22023978,022-22021714,(Mobile)
09969201364} & alternate DAE -ECR {022-25991070, 022-25515283, (Mobile)
099692013651}. In addition, it is envisaged that the concerned public official will follow
their own SOP & intimate the concemed agencies for ensuring appropriate response,

2) Expert response agencies (Police NDRF/relevant state authorities) after reaching t°
incident spot, if feel that they need an expert advice or technical support from nodal ministry
(DAE); they should contact CMG, DAE through DAE-Emergency Control room. While
informing, they are requested to provide exact location, contract numbers of concemed
DM/SP/Local police station and details of incident with brief description of the object (if
possible, along with photograph taken from the distance).

3) Upon receipt of such information, the CMG, DAE will get activated and will get in
touch with the local authorities to decide about further course of action.
16:
4) CMG will decide and constitute a team of experts as per requirements. The team of
experts will be dispatched to the site by quickest means possible,

5) _ Member Secretary, CMG (who is also the designated Nodal Officer of DAE) will get
regular updates from concerned DAE experts/field agencies and will keep concerned
authorities informed and as per scenario, will also keep MHA Control Room updated.

6) DAE experts on recovery/retrieval of the source will examine the integrity of the
radiation source & accordingly, ADRD will decide about further course of action regarding
safe keeping/disposal of the material.

7) _ Responsibility of source transportation of radioactive material from incident site to a
safe storage place should be under taken by local police.

8) _ If there is local contamination due to radioactive material, decontamination activities
should be taken up by expert response agencies like NDRF and or be performed under
guidance of DAEs technical experts. Local district authorities should provide adequate
resources for handling and transportation of the contaminated material to the safe disposal
site.

9) Incase required, media briefing will be done by the designated state official. He may
seek Technical inputs from AERB, if he desires.

10) After recovery/retrieval of the source and after completing of activities related with
decontamination and safe disposal (as per scenario requirements), with due concurrence of
AERB, the closure of radiological emergency scenario will be declared by the concerned
DM/SP.

9.2 DO}

For response to radiological Emergency: -

1) Don’t send untrained responders/volunteers.
2) Don't send trained responders without proper PPEs and detection equipment.
3) Don’t send responders without taking proper guidance.

The other relevant clause of the latest CMP document related with radiological equipment
and related with the caution for danger of radiation and its handling is to be synchronized
with this SOP during the radiological emergencies.
